pages:
Regional Technical Assistance Report
 
Project Number: 39341 
December 2007 
 
 
 
Capacity Development on Involuntary Resettlement  
 
 
 
The views expressed herein are those of the consultant and do not necessarily represent those of ADB’s 
members, Board of Directors, Management, or staff, and may be preliminary in nature.

ABBREVIATIONS 
 
 
  ADB  –  Asian Development Bank 
  BAPPENAS   –  Badan Perencanaan Pembangunan Nasional  
(National Development Planning Agency) 
  MONRE   –  Ministry of Natural Resources and Environment (Viet Nam) 
  RSES  –  Environment and Social Safeguards Division  
  TA  –  technical assistance 
 
 
 
TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE CLASSIFICATION 
 
 
Targeting Classification  –  General intervention 
Sector  –  Health, nutrition, and social protection  
Subsector  –  Other social services and social development  
Themes  –  Inclusive social development, capacity development, gender and 
development  
Subthemes  –  Involuntary resettlement, institutional development, gender equity 
in empowerment and rights  
 
 
 
 
NOTE 
 
In this report, "$" refers to US dollars. 
 
 
 
 
Vice President  U. Schaefer-Preuss, Knowledge Management and Sustainable 
Development 
Director General  X. Yao, Regional and Sustainable Development Department (RSDD)  
Director  N. Ahmad, Environment and Social Safeguard Division, RSDD  
   
Team leader  R. A. Jayewardene, Senior Social Development Specialist, RSDD  
Team member  K. Schmidt-Soltau, Social Safeguard Specialist, RSDD

I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  This  regional  technical  assistance  (TA)  builds  on  the  experience  of  the  Asian 
Development Bank (ADB) in implementing its Involuntary Resettlement Policy (1995). Gaps 
between ADB’s policy and national laws and procedures, including inadequate resources within 
ADB and governments, pose the most critical challenges to effective policy implementation. 
ADB resource input is required at two levels to support government efforts: (i) developing 
national  policy,  including  improvements  to  systems  and  procedures;  and  (ii)  providing 
competent  staff  to  support  loan  preparation  and  implementation  both  within  ADB  and  the 
governments.  The  TA  fact-finding  mission,1  consultations  with  resident  mission  staff  and 
Headquarters  staff  helped  refine  and  finalize  the  TA  activities.  The  resident  mission  staff 
particularly in Bangladesh and Viet Nam, requested further support for training activities. Due to 
budget limitation, the TA cannot accommodate additional training. However, it is expected that 
the resettlement specialists to be fielded in the resident missions will play an active role in 
training. 
 
2.  An Operations Evaluation Department study concluded that insufficient supervision by 
ADB impedes satisfactory delivery of safeguards under the Involuntary Resettlement Policy.2  It 
also stated that ADB technical assistance (TA) on involuntary resettlement, although relatively 
small, has had a positive impact. Thus, it recommended enhanced TA support.  
 
3.  To address the pressing need of lack of staff capacity within resident missions, the main 
activity under the TA is to support the placement of resettlement specialists in resident missions 
in Bangladesh, Indonesia, and Viet Nam for 3 years.3 The country directors in these countries 
have expressed strong support for augmenting resources in the resident missions. The TA will 
also  provide  support  for  (i)  capacity  development  to  selected  agencies  in  Indonesia  and 
Pakistan, and (ii) specialist support to the Government of Viet Nam to support its efforts to 
revise  the land  law.  Bangladesh and  Viet  Nam  have  a  large  infrastructure  portfolio  under 
implementation and in the pipeline. In Indonesia, the resident mission has been extending the 
services of a staff consultant recruited in 2006 on a yearly basis. 4
 
4.  The  TA  will  also  support  a  request  from  the  Government  of  Viet  Nam  to  finance 
international  experts  to  increase  efforts  to  review  and  revise  Viet  Nam’s  land  law.  The 
Government of Viet Nam is facing increasing demands from the public to be paid adequate 
compensation  for  lands  acquired,  and  local  governments  are  facing  difficulty  in  accessing 
replacement  lands.  The  Office  of  the  Government  has  requested  the  Ministry  of  Natural 
Resources and Environment (MONRE) to prepare recommendations for revising the land law, 
and studies are already under way. In Indonesia, the National Planning and Development 
Agency, BAPPENAS (Monitoring and Evaluation of Development Funding), stressed the need 
for “quality at entry”, early identification of land acquisition and resettlement impacts, and timely 
implementation.  The  Government  of  Indonesia  has  recommended  capacity  development 
                                                 
1 A fact-finding mission was fielded on 22 October–2 November 2007 to Indonesia and Viet Nam. The mission 
comprised R. Jayewardene, Senior Social Development Specialist/Mission Leader, Regional and Sustainable 
Development Department (RSDD), Environment and Social Safeguards Division (RSES).  
2  ADB. 2006. Special Evaluation Study on Involuntary Resettlement.    
3  Resident missions in Cambodia, People’s Republic of China, India, Lao People’s Democratic Republic, Nepal, 
Pakistan, and Sri Lanka already have resettlement specialists.   
4  Implementation of the TA will not commence until no-objection letters have been received by the respective 
governments.

2    
support  to  be  provided  at  the  regional  level.  The  design  and  monitoring  framework  is  in 
Appendix 1.5 
 
II.  ISSUES 
5.  The absence of dedicated qualified staff means that ADB engagement with executing 
agencies and other stakeholders on Involuntary Resettlement is at best intermittent except 
through TA grants, intermittent orientation seminars by the Environment and Social Safeguards 
Division  (RSES),  and  project-specific  capacity  development.  Lack  of  ADB  resettlement 
specialists at field level, and the inability of executing agencies to engage with staff on a 
frequent basis, were cited as key drawbacks during the regional workshop held in Manila in 
2005.6 In contrast, the World Bank has three social safeguard specialists in Viet Nam and at 
least two each in its Bangladesh and Indonesia country offices.    
 
6.  The TA countries (Bangladesh, Indonesia, Pakistan, and Viet Nam) increasingly face the 
challenge of rationalizing development demands and land scarcity. Much publicity surrounds 
such investment initiatives in emerging economies such as the People’s Republic of China, 
India, and Viet Nam. Land acquisition is devolved under the purview of provinces and districts in 
Pakistan, Indonesia, and Viet Nam. Efforts to improve resettlement implementation in these 
countries must focus on the relevant decentralized agencies. 
 
7.  During TA fact-finding in Viet Nam, MONRE and the Ministry of Finance confirmed that 
the Government of Viet Nam urgently needs to address land acquisition and resettlement issues 
satisfactorily, and reduce dissatisfaction among affected groups. The Government of Viet Nam 
has begun a process of reviewing current laws and procedures, including property valuation. 
MONRE confirmed that its staff in the provinces and districts has limited capacity to implement 
the existing provisions, particularly in more remote locations.  
 
8.   Indonesia has an expropriation law but it was only invoked once in 1972. Complex land 
laws,  coupled  with  decentralized  decision-making,  have  precluded  needed  investment  in 
infrastructure. During the Infrastructure Summit held in Jakarta in January 2005, land acquisition 
and  resettlement  was  one  of  the  key  issues  raised  by  BAPPENAS.  Considerable 
implementation  delays  and  less-than-optimal  project  benefits  are  caused  by  protracted 
negotiations for land acquisition; decentralized responsibilities; and lack of understanding of 
ADB policy requirements, including approaches to addressing gaps between ADB requirements 
on Involuntary Resettlement and national law. 
 
9.  ADB is currently implementing a large infrastructure development program in Pakistan 
and the Government of Pakistan is reviewing the need for improved legislation on resettlement. 
In the interim, to facilitate implementation of projects and provide greater understanding of 
involuntary resettlement, training will be provided to key agencies. ADB’s Central and West Asia 
Department has requested that such training be particularly in the infrastructure sector. The TA 
will focus on sectors where ADB loans result in large-scale land acquisition and resettlement. 
The training program will be designed to suit the needs of executing agencies and stakeholders 
in the provinces.  
 
                                                 
5  The concept paper was cleared by ADB Management on 27 July 2006. The TA first appeared in ADB Business 
Opportunities on 19 November 2007. 
6  ADB. 2002. Technical Assistance for Capacity Building on Resettlement Risk Management (TA 6091-REG, 
approved on 19 December, for $500,000).

3
10.  With dedicated consultant support available, ADB will be better positioned to respond to 
its development partners and engage in regular interaction with stakeholders—not only on 
project-specific issues but also on policy dialogue and demand-driven capacity support.  
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
11.  The  overall  impact  of  the  regional  TA  is  improved  implementation,  and  better 
understanding by government and development partners, of ADB’s policy requirements on 
involuntary  resettlement.  The  outcome  of  the  TA  is  enhanced  integration  of  involuntary 
resettlement requirements in ADB operations.     
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
12.  The  outputs  of  the  TA  will  comprise  (i)  resettlement  technical  support  to  resident 
missions  and  headquarters  for  implementing  ADB’s  policy  requirements  on  Involuntary 
Resettlement, (ii) capacity development in Indonesia and Pakistan and (iii) technical support for 
enhancing legal frameworks in Viet Nam. The TA will be delivered through three components to 
be implemented over 3 years: 
 
(i)  Component  1.  Local  consultants  will  be  placed  in  resident  missions  in 
Bangladesh, Indonesia and Viet Nam for 3 years to provide support to ADB and 
government  in  policy  implementation.  RSES,  in  consultation  with  regional 
departments and resident missions, will select the resettlement specialists and 
provide training and supervision.   
 
(ii)  Component  2.  Selective  capacity  development  support  will  be  provided  in 
Indonesia  and  Pakistan  based  on  consultations  with  regional  departments, 
resident  missions,  government,  and  counterpart  agencies.  The  training  will 
primarily  consist  of  in-house  and  field-based  training.  Relevant  technical 
guidance notes will be prepared.  
 
(iii)  Component 3. International specialists’ expertise will be provided to support the 
enhancement of the land law in Viet Nam. Specifically, support will be provided in 
international best practice on land laws and asset valuation. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
13.  The total cost of the TA is estimated to be $800,000 equivalent. The TA will be financed 
on a grant basis by ADB’s TA funding program. The cost estimates cover consulting services, 
training and workshops, airfares, per diems, workshops, translation, domestic transport, and 
administrative costs. The cost estimates are in Appendix 2. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
14.  ADB will be the Executing Agency for the TA and RSES will be responsible for overall 
administration.  The  TA  will  be  implemented  over  3  years,  tentatively  commencing  in 
February 2008  with  an  expected  completion  date  of  February  2011.  Component  1  will  be 
implemented in Bangladesh, Indonesia, and Viet Nam. The resettlement specialists will function

4    
under  the  guidance  of  the  country  director  and  RSES.  The  focal  agencies  for  capacity 
development will be BAPPENAS in Indonesia and the National Highway Authority in Pakistan.   
 
15.  In Viet Nam, MONRE will be the focal agency for component 2. MONRE has already 
established a working group to conduct reviews and assessments of the existing land law and 
its implementation. It will play a key role in guiding the diagnostic and defining key support 
required by the consultant.  
  
16.  In Indonesia, implementation of component 2 will be coordinated with BAPPENAS, the 
resident mission and the regional departments. They will provide guidance on the focus of the 
training, and selection of participating agencies and candidates.  
 
17.  In  Pakistan,  identification  of  participants  and  training  needs  will  be  prepared  in 
consultation with the regional department, resident mission, and ADB partner agencies. The 
infrastructure sector will be a key focus of the training.  
 
18.  Consultant  input  for  the  following  activities  is  required  for  the  TA:  (i)  resettlement 
capacity development, (ii) land law, (iii) land and property valuation, and (iv) training. Activities 
performed under the TA are expected to require 162 person-months of consulting services, 
comprising 18 person-months of international consulting and 144 person-months of national 
consulting services. International consultant support will be provided intermittently over the TA 
implementation period, including the home office and the field. Outline terms of reference for 
consultants are in Appendix 3. Individual consultants will be engaged by ADB in accordance 
with its Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2007, as amended from time to time). The 
international specialists will work in close coordination with the national resettlement specialists, 
and maintain regular contact with the respective country directors. They will report directly to 
RSES. No procurement will be needed.  
 
19.  The selection of resettlement specialists to be located in the resident missions will be 
undertaken by RSES, the respective regional departments, and resident missions. RSES and 
the  relevant  representatives  of  each  regional  department  and  resident  mission  will  be 
responsible for interviewing, ranking, and selection of the candidates. Initially, each specialist 
will be recruited for 1 year with an option for extension of up to 3 years, based on the first year’s 
performance.  The  work  program  will  be  closely  coordinated  among  RSES,  the  regional 
departments, and resident missions. On project-specific work, the specialist will work closely 
with the respective team leader and operational department resettlement specialist and the 
resident mission. On a day-to-day basis, the specialists will report to and work under the 
guidance of the country director, with technical support from RSES and the regional department 
resettlement specialist. The resident missions will provide logistical support to the specialist, 
including  office  space,  furniture,  and  administrative  support.  The  specialists  will  prepare 
semiannual progress reports to RSES, the regional departments, and the country director. The 
specialists will participate in semiannual workshops at ADB headquarters to share experience 
and disseminate knowledge.   
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
20.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $800,000 on a grant basis for 
Capacity Development on Involuntary Resettlement, and hereby reports this action to the Board.

8  Appendix 3 
 
 
OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
  
 
A.  National Resettlement Specialists (3 consultants, 108 person-months) 
1.  The  consultant  will  provide  the  following  outputs  to  support  implementation  of  policy 
requirements on involuntary resettlement of the Asian Development Bank (ADB). 
(i)  Support resident missions, operations departments, and ADB partner agencies in 
systematic implementation of ADB’s policy requirements on involuntary resettlement   
in ADB operations. 
(ii)  Support capacity building within resident missions and ADB partner agencies. 
(iii)  Engage  in  dialogue  with  stakeholders  and  support  ADB  initiatives  in  policy 
development.  
(iv)  Engage with stakeholders, including other financing agencies and civil society, in 
raising awareness on ADB’s policy requirements on involuntary resettlement. 
(v)  Prepare semiannual progress reports on implementation of the work program. 
(vi)  Prepare technical guidance notes for partner agencies.  
(vii)  Prepare  presentations  for  the  semiannual  workshops  to  be  held  at  ADB   
headquarters. 
 
2.  The consultant will play a key role in mainstreaming policy requirements on involuntary 
resettlement within ADB operations, including raising awareness within the technical assistance 
(TA)  countries.  The  consultant  will  be  expected  to  provide  increased  project  supervision  on 
involuntary  resettlement.  While  the  consultant  will  report  to  the  country  director  and  ADB’s 
Environment and Social Safeguards Division (RSES), he/she will be required to develop a work 
program in close coordination with regional department specialists and operations divisions to 
complement their work and expand coverage of policy implementation. 
3.  The  consultant  is  expected  to  keep  abreast  of  developments  on  land  acquisition  and 
resettlement in the respective country, and keep ADB informed of developments through the 
resettlement network and regular engagement with colleagues and the country director.      
 
B.  International Land Law Specialist (6 person-months, intermittent) 
4.  The specialist will provide the necessary support and input to reviews and assessments 
being undertaken by the focal agency. He/she will support legal drafting and offer guidance on 
international best practice. The following activities will be carried out by the consultant: 
(i)  Provide  expert  review  and  recommendations  on  outputs  prepared  by  the  focal 
agency. 
(ii)  Support  the  agency  through  desk  review  and  field-based  assessments  on  key 
elements of the land law and its implementation. 
(iii)  Provide support through reference and exposure to international best practice. 
(iv)  Support local teams in legal drafting and other relevant guidance as requested.  
(v)  Prepare key guidance notes or contributions to the work of the focal agency as 
requested. 
 
5.  The consultant’s work will be expected to coordinate the work program and specialized 
activities with the focal agency, RSES, the resident mission, and regional department resettlement 
specialist.

Appendix 3  9 
 
C.  International Land and Property Valuation Specialist (6 person-months, intermittent)  
6.  Under the guidance of the focal agency and ADB, the consultant will be required to review 
the outputs of the focal agency and provide recommendations consistent with international best 
practice. The consultant will also be required to undertake field assessments of current practice in 
asset valuation, and make recommendations from the findings of the field-based assessments. 
He/she  will  be  required  to  review  current  methodology  systems,  and  process  and  provide 
recommendations  for  improved  valuation  methodology  (including  procedure  and  improved 
transparency). 
 
D.  International Resettlement Specialist (3 person-months, intermittent) 
7.  The international resettlement specialist will prepare a training program to raise awareness 
of ADB’s requirements on Involuntary Resettlement; and deliver training programs that address 
local resettlement practice, international best practice, and ADB policy and practice. The specialist 
will conduct the following activities: 
 
(i)  Identify training needs and prepare a training program to be delivered at national 
and local level in consultation with the resident mission, operations departments, 
and ADB partner agencies. 
(ii)  Develop a training program schedule, an outline for the training program, and key 
materials to be delivered—on completion of a desk review of ADB project reports 
and consultations with key stakeholders. 
(iii)  Prepare interactive technical guidance notes for specific sectors, on completion of 
the  training  program  and  taking  into  account  discussions  during  the  training 
sessions.  
(iv)  Prepare an inception report and a draft and final report, on completion of the training 
in each country. 
 
E.  International Training Specialist (3 person-months, intermittent) 
8.  The training specialist will work in close coordination with the international resettlement 
specialist  to  prepare  and  deliver  the  training  program.  The  specialist  will  ensure  delivery  of 
interactive training materials, and provide input to the draft and final report on the training program. 
 
F.  National Administration Specialist (36 person-months)  
 
9.  A national TA administration specialist will be recruited on an individual basis to deal with 
day-to-day administration; and coordinate activities between RSES, regional departments, and 
resident missions. The specialist will undertake the following tasks: 
 
(i)  Carry out necessary administrative tasks to ensure timely implementation of TA 
activities, and coordination within ADB and externally. 
(ii)  Support the preparation and organization of semiannual workshops at headquarters. 
(iii)  Provide support as necessary to the consultant team; and act as liaison between the 
consultants, government, RSES, resident missions, and regional departments. 
(iv)  Provide support as required to ensure smooth implementation of TA activities.
